title: Newtons second law - determining new force

content.question: Two horizontal forces cause an object to move with an acceleration <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> to the right. The force <math alttext="F sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>L</mtext></msub></math> is exerted to the left, with magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math>, and the force <math alttext="F sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub></math> is exerted to the right, with magnitude <math alttext="3 F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>F</mi></math>. What would the magnitude of <math alttext="F sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub></math> need to be to cause the object to move with an acceleration of <math alttext="4 a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi></math> to the right while <math alttext="F sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>L</mtext></msub></math> remains unchanged?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
